title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income, with no double benefit allowed for expenses covered by other provisions or grants. The Adoption Assistance Act allows a credit for qualified adoption expenses, excluding funds received from other programs. Qualified adoption expenses include fees directly related to legal adoption, not violating any laws. The Adoption Assistance Act provides a tax credit for qualified adoption expenses, excluding those related to the adoption of a spouse's child. Married couples must file joint returns for this credit. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the law. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Title II of the document focuses on adoption assistance for federal employees, specifically addressing reimbursement for adoption expenses. The effective date for the amendments mentioned in this section is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. Title II of the document discusses adoption benefits for federal employees, including reimbursement for adoption expenses. Adoption expenses refer to reasonable and necessary costs directly related to the adoption of a child, such as fees charged by an adoption agency. The term 'adoption expenses' for a child includes fees from adoption agencies, legal fees, counseling fees, medical expenses, foster-care charges, and transportation expenses. Agency heads must establish a program to reimburse employees for these expenses when adopting a child. Agency heads must establish a program to reimburse employees for adoption expenses incurred when adopting a child, including transportation expenses. Reimbursement is subject to certain conditions, such as the child being under 18 years of age and unmarried at the time of finalization of the adoption. Employees must submit a written application within the specified timeframe to be eligible for reimbursement. Reimbursement for adoption expenses is subject to conditions, including a maximum limit of $2,000 per child. Both adopting parents may be eligible for reimbursement, but no payment is made if both parents are eligible. The reimbursement for adoption expenses is subject to conditions, with a maximum limit of $4,000 per child. Both adopting parents may be eligible for reimbursement, but no payment is made if it would exceed the total adoption expenses incurred. Guidelines for interagency cooperation and payment provisions are included in the guidelines issued under this section. The Office of Personnel Management may issue guidelines for uniform administration of reimbursement for adoption expenses under this section. Executive agencies must follow these guidelines in their regulations. The Office may also provide assistance to agencies upon request. The analysis for part III of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include "SUBPART G--ANNUITIES, INSURANCE, AND MISCELLANEOUS BENEFITS" and "90. Miscellaneous Employee Benefits" under chapter 89. Section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, is also amended to apply Section 9001 of title 5 to the Postal Service. Regulations must be consistent with guidelines issued under this section. The title will be effective on October 1, 1995, applying to adoptions finalized on or after that date. Title III excludes adoption assistance under section 137 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employee adoption assistance benefits and military adoption assistance benefits received by an employee for adopting a child are not considered as gross income. Employee adoption assistance benefits refer to payments by an employer for adoption expenses, while military adoption assistance benefits are benefits provided to military personnel for adoption. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' refers to necessary fees and costs directly related to legal adoption of an eligible child, not violating any laws. The term 'eligible child' refers to an individual under 18 or mentally/physically incapable of self-care, eligible for adoption by the taxpayer without violating any laws. The Secretary will issue regulations to coordinate this section with other tax provisions related to adoption expenses.
